title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001" and includes findings and purposes. The Arabia Mountain area contains natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources that represent the heritage of the United States. Managing these resources through partnerships between public and private entities is the best approach. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia is a 535-acre park. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain, located in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park, is a rare example of a pristine granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve contains evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, and related sites are also of interest. The South River shows early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote historical sites. The National Register of Historic Places Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in areas like Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, and Miners Creek. It also assists Georgia and counties in developing a cultural and historical management program. The National Register of Historic Places Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in areas like Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, and Miners Creek. It also assists in implementing an integrated cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect, enhance, and interpret significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "heritage area" as Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area, "management entity" as Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance, "management plan" as the plan developed for the heritage area, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" as the State of Georgia. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Established the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in the State, consisting of certain parcels of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map depicting the boundaries is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is designated as the management entity. SEC. 5. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF THE MANAGEMENT ENTITY. The management entity has the authority to make grants, enter agreements, hire staff, and enter contracts for goods and services. They are also responsible for developing and submitting the management plan to the Secretary. The management entity is responsible for developing and implementing a management plan for the heritage area, considering the interests of various groups. Priorities include assisting in resource preservation and encouraging local governments to adopt land use measures. The management entity is responsible for developing and implementing a management plan for the heritage area, focusing on resource preservation and encouraging local governments to adopt compatible land use policies. Public meetings are held quarterly to discuss plan implementation, and an annual report is submitted to the Secretary detailing activities when Federal funds are utilized. The management entity must submit an annual report to the Secretary outlining their accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to provide all expenditure records for audit and ensure compliance with agreements for Federal fund expenditures. The management entity must provide expenditure records for audit and comply with agreements for Federal fund expenditures. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property. The management entity can use Federal funds from other sources for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area that integrates efforts to protect, interpret, and enhance its resources based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. The plan should also consider State and local plans and involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations in the area. The management plan for the heritage area shall consider State and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources that should be preserved or maintained due to their significance. The management plan for the heritage area includes an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation. The management plan for the heritage area includes actions to be carried out by various entities to protect resources, identification of funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to do so will result in a halt of additional funding until the plan is submitted. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the management plan. The management entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Funding will be halted until the plan is submitted. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days. The Secretary shall advise the management entity of reasons for disapproval, make recommendations for revisions, and allow for resubmission of the management plan within 90 days of revision submission. After the Secretary approves a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the revision within 90 days of submission. The management entity must submit recommendations for revisions to the management plan, which must be approved by the Secretary before any funds can be used for implementation. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to heritage areas for developing and implementing management plans, prioritizing actions that conserve natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources, as well as providing educational and recreational opportunities consistent with the area's values. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50%. Secretary's authority terminates on September 30, 2016.
